examples: a cup of tea or coffee
I either take taxis or walk everywhere
it doesn't matter whether the theory is right or wrong

conjunction.description: Introducing a synonym or explanation of a preceding word or phrase.
examples: the espionage novel, or, as it is known in the trade, the thriller

conjunction.description: Otherwise (used to introduce the consequences of something not being done or not being the case)
examples: hurry up, or you'll miss it all

conjunction.description: Introducing an afterthought, usually in the form of a question.
examples: John's indifference—or was it?—left her unsettled
to love is the one way to know or God or man

noun.description: A Boolean operator that gives the value one if at least one operand (or input) has a value of one, and otherwise has a value of zero.

abbreviation.description: Other ranks (as opposed to commissioned officers).

phrases: Rob failed to get a bite, and after an hour or so, he suggested that we try further upstream.
José Luis is in his forties and has a group of a dozen or so mates he has been hanging out with all his life.
You cut them into squares and blanch them in boiling water for a minute or so with onion and garlic.
I will be away from my computer for the next week or so, and will be taking a break from blogging.
origin: Early 16th century: from French, from Latin aurum gold.
